prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for asking my bulimic roommate to control herself?
I (F20) have been living with my roommate (F20) for about a year now. We’ve already made plans to move out and live with other people in a few months (unrelated to any of this). For the most part, she’s a really good roommate; she pays everything on time, cleans the whole apartment, is very quiet, and even though we aren’t friends per se we are friendly and get along pretty well.


She doesn’t really cook, and her side of the fridge/her cupboards are pretty much bare (like she literally just has condiments in the fridge right now). I enjoy cooking and am on a bit of a budget (I support myself) so I cook 3 meals a day, 7 days a week (since I can’t afford to eat out). 


Starting when we first moved in, I started noticing things were off with my food. Not that things were missing (although sometimes I would have less of something than I thought) but also that I would sometimes have more, of a different product than I remember buying (ie going to eat some crackers and them being kinda whole grain-y despite the box saying original). I didn’t really think much of it, or just assumed I was being absent minded.


Lately though, it’s been getting much worse and it’s clear she’s taking my food and trying to replace it (hence the products sometimes being slightly different). I’ve gone into the cupboards and found unopened packages of things that I KNOW I’ve already opened.


Last week I confronted her about this and she broke down crying and told me she’s been bulimic for a wrong time, she knows it’s wrong, but she can’t help binging on my food sometimes, blah blah. Also that she doesn’t want to be like this but she’s stuck on a waitlist for treatment. She was very upset and apologetic but I was still mad at her. I told her that I’m sorry she has that issue but it shouldn’t be my problem and if she needs to eat she can just buy her own food since her parents support her. She pointed out that she replaces everything she takes but it still bothers me knowing that someone is eating MY food. I understand there’s something wrong with her but it’s not like she can’t control herself at the grocery store and eats right off the shelves, or at restaurants takes from other people’s tables. I told her that and I don’t understand why this is any different; it’s not socially acceptable to take other people’s property regardless of what’s wrong with you. 


She cried in her room for a long time and we haven’t spoken or made eye contact since then, although I’m trying to be nice. I feel bad but I also don’t think I actually did anything wrong. We’re both 20, IMO it’s not unreasonable to expect her to control herself. Like do I want to eat a whole box of cookies? Sure, but I don’t because I know better. I’m just asking her to exercise the same restraint here. 


Am I the asshole?

"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the person who asked this question is in the wrong. The situation is about their roommate being bulimic and taking their food. The user is upset because they cook a lot and are on a budget, and they found their food missing or replaced. They confronted the roommate, who admitted to taking the food due to her bulimia. The user told the roommate to buy her own food, and now they're asking if they're the asshole.

First, I need to consider the roommate's situation. Bulimia is a serious eating disorder that can be really hard to control, especially without treatment. The roommate is on a waitlist for help, so she's not just being careless. She's struggling with a mental health issue. The user's roommate is paying her share, cleaning, etc., so she's not being negligent in other areas. 

On the other hand, the user is cooking a lot and is supporting themselves. Their food is their property, and having someone take it without permission feels violated. They're within their rights to expect others to respect their belongings. However, the user's response was to confront the roommate, which led to emotional distress. The user also mentioned that the roommate replaces the food, but the user is still upset about their property being taken. 

The user's argument is that the roommate should control herself, similar to how they control themselves when they don't eat a whole box of cookies. But bulimia is a compulsion, not just a lack of willpower. It's not that simple to just "stop." The user's comment about not taking from grocery stores or restaurants might be a bit hypocritical, but in those cases, the food isn't owned by others in the same way as shared living spaces. 

The question is whether the user overstepped. The user did confront the roommate, which is reasonable because they were upset. However, the way they responded—telling the roommate to buy her own food and implying it's her problem—might not be the best approach, especially considering the roommate's mental health. The user might not be the asshole because they have a right to their belongings, but they could have handled it more sensitively. Alternatively, maybe the roommate should have found another solution instead of taking the food. 

But given the circumstances, the user is in a difficult position. They're not being cruel, just asserting their boundaries. The roommate's actions are problematic, but the user isn't wrong for standing up for themselves. The answer might be B, the user isn't the asshole. However, some might argue the user should have offered support instead of just telling her to control herself. But the user's main point is about ownership and control, which is valid. So probably B is the right choice here.
